items.title: The Elon Musk Act aims to ban ‘special government employees’ from having federal contracts
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- U.S. Representative Mark Pocan introduces the ELON MUSK Act to prohibit 'special government employees' from federal contracts.
- The act aims to prevent conflicts of interest, particularly citing Elon Musk's significant federal contract history.
- Musk's involvement with federal agencies, including a controversial advisory role, raises concerns about ethical breaches and public influence.
- The bill coincides with protests and bipartisan legislative efforts to restrict Musk's access to government systems.

items.title: New target of Paragon spyware comes forward
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Mediterranea Saving Humans announced one of its founders, Luca Casarini, was targeted by Paragon spyware.
- WhatsApp disrupted a campaign targeting around 90 individuals, including journalists and civil society members, using Paragon spyware.
- Other targets include journalist Francesco Cancellato and activist Husam El Gomati, all critical of the current Italian government.

items.title: Workday cuts nearly 2,000 employees
items.summary:
- Workday laid off 1,750 employees, about 8.5% of its workforce.
- CEO Carl Eschenbach stated the need for a new approach in the current market.
- The company plans to hire AI talent in the future.
- Other tech companies also announced recent layoffs, including Okta and Cruise.

items.title: AI’s biggest stage awaits – TechCrunch Sessions: AI tickets available
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI is now open for registration, with discounts up to $300 on select tickets.
- The event is scheduled for June 5 at Zellerbach Hall, UC Berkeley, gathering 1,200 industry leaders for talks and discussions.
- Attendees can network, learn, and connect with AI innovators and investors.
- More details and registration available on the [TechCrunch Sessions: AI event page](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-sessions-ai/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=tcsessionsai&utm_content=post_sebannouncement_02052025&promo=post_sebannouncement_02052025&display=).

items.title: Tickets on sale: TechCrunch All Stage 2025, formerly known as Early Stage
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Early Stage has evolved into TechCrunch All Stage 2025, taking place in Boston on July 17.
- Early bird tickets available, saving up to $310 on select types.
- Event covers all stages of scaling a business, with insights for both early and late-stage founders.
- Topics include Series A fundraising, pitch deck creation, scaling to $10M ARR, and going public strategies.
- Networking opportunities available through Braindate.
- Notable past speakers include partners from Sequoia Capital, NFX, and more.
- Registration for tickets is currently open at the best prices.

items.title: Google launches new AI models and brings ‘thinking’ to Gemini
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google launched Gemini 2.0 Pro Experimental, its new flagship AI model, on Wednesday.
- The Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking model is now available in the Gemini app, enhancing its reasoning capabilities.
- The new Gemini Pro model excels in coding and complex prompts, boasting a context window of 2 million tokens.
- Google aims to compete with DeepSeek's cost-effective AI models, which have gained significant attention.

items.title: Musk moves to dismiss suit over Tesla’s alleged use of AI-generated ‘Blade Runner’ imagery
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Attorneys for Elon Musk plan to dismiss a lawsuit accusing him and Tesla of using AI-generated, copyright-violating ‘Blade Runner’-inspired images.
- The filing was submitted to the U.S. District Court Central District of California, requesting that all claims be dismissed with prejudice, meaning they cannot be refiled.
- Alcon Entertainment, the plaintiff and producer of ‘Blade Runner 2049’, intends to oppose Musk's motion to dismiss the case, which was filed in October claiming infringement of IP rights.

items.title: Cherry Ventures raises a new $500M fund for early stage and beyond, but will it be enough?
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Cherry Ventures has closed a $500 million fund for early-stage and follow-on rounds at Series B and beyond.
- The firm aims to build the "first trillion dollar company in Europe," challenging the perception of Europe’s VC landscape.
- In comparison, European AI startups raised $8 billion in 2024, while U.S. AI startups secured $97 billion.
- Venture capital funding for U.K. startups fell by 50% to approximately $2.9 billion in October.
- Cherry Ventures did not feature in last year’s HEC-Dow Jones Venture Capital Performance Ranking.
- The VC’s previous fund was €300 million ($312 million) announced in early 2022.
- Notable LPs in the new fund include entrepreneurs from Wolt, Supercell, and Flix.

items.title: CodeSignal wants you to practice soft skills with its AI-powered guide
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- CodeSignal launches soft skill courses on its platform, using AI to practice professional skills and work-life scenarios.
- The platform offers over 100 courses covering topics like leadership, sales training, and negotiation tactics.
- Users can interact with an AI assistant for feedback, with extended features available for a fee of $24.99.

items.title: Shein hit with consumer protection action in EU as bloc unboxes strategy to tackle low-cost ecommerce risks
items.summary:
[ Shein, the Chinese ecommerce giant, is facing scrutiny from the EU's Consumer Protection Cooperation Network (CPCN) regarding consumer protection rules. ]
[ The EU launched a coordinated action referencing various directives due to concerns over products failing to meet safety standards. ]
[ The EU reported that approximately 4.6 billion low-value consignments entered the market, raising health, safety, environmental, and competition issues. ]

items.title: Modern Synthesis is making compostable materials that last a lifetime
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Jen Keane's startup, Modern Synthesis, innovatively grows and processes nanocellulose fibers for sustainable materials.
- The materials created are biodegradable and can mimic synthetic materials like leather while aiming for a lifespan of 100 years.
- Modern Synthesis closed a $5.5 million funding round to increase production and explore applications like smart textiles and car dashboards.

items.title: Former Whoop exec’s new app Alma uses AI for all things nutrition
items.author: Rami Alhamad
items.summary:
- Former VP of product at Whoop, Rami Alhamad, launched an iOS app called Alma, which offers AI-driven nutrition tracking.
- The app allows users to interact via text or voice to log food, or take pictures for dish identification.
- Users can receive meal suggestions tailored to their nutritional goals and receive diet improvement tips based on intake scores.
- Alma is expected to generate revenue through a monthly subscription of $19 or an annual fee of $199.
- The app aims to simplify nutrition tracking compared to existing solutions like MyFitnessPal.

items.title: Waymo just popped up on the Uber app in Austin ahead of robotaxi launch
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Uber customers in Austin can now express interest in a Waymo robotaxi through the app.
- The interest list is part of a partnership between Uber and Waymo to launch a robotaxi service in Austin and Atlanta in early 2025.
- Waymo's service will allow Uber users to hail autonomous Jaguar I-PACE vehicles in a designated area of Austin and will expand over time.

items.title: Router maker Zyxel tells customers to replace vulnerable hardware exploited by hackers
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Taiwanese hardware maker Zyxel has revealed it will not patch two critical vulnerabilities affecting thousands of routers.
- The vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-40890 and CVE-2024-40891, allow hackers to execute arbitrary commands, leading to system compromise and data exfiltration.
- Zyxel advises customers to replace vulnerable routers with newer models instead of providing patches, as the affected devices have reached end-of-life status.

items.title: European AI startups raised $8 billion in 2024
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- In 2024, European AI startups raised approximately $8 billion, capturing around 20% of total VC funding in the region.
- Major AI investment hubs in Europe include the U.K., France, Germany, and the Nordics.
- U.S. VC firms contribute to 50% of investments in AI companies at Series C and beyond.

items.title: European AI startups have raised $8 billion in 2024
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- In 2024, European AI startups secured around $8 billion in funding, representing about 20% of all VC funding in the region.
- Significant investments and announcements are expected from the upcoming Artificial Intelligence Action Summit in France, with many global tech leaders attending.
- The U.K. leads AI investments in Europe, followed by France and Germany, while 70% of funding was allocated for seed to Series B rounds.
- U.S. VC firms account for 50% of investments in AI companies at Series C rounds and above.
- Health and climate sectors are key focus areas for AI startups in France, with companies like Owkin leading innovations in the health tech sector.
- AI is also being utilized to create new climate-related startups, including agritech and energy management ventures.

items.title: Hitachi Ventures raises $400M fund to invest in everything from fusion to AI
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Hitachi Ventures raised $400 million for its fourth fund aimed at deep tech investments.
- The fund will focus on sectors like energy, manufacturing, biotech, AI, and more, including emerging technologies like quantum and nuclear.
- Average initial investments will be around $5 million, with 55% of capital reserved for follow-on opportunities.
- The fund operates more like a typical venture fund but maintains a close relationship with Hitachi for potential future customer insights.
- Past investments include companies in energy and AI, highlighting a diverse portfolio in innovative sectors.

items.title: Google wants Search to be more like an AI assistant in 2025
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google CEO Sundar Pichai announced a significant shift in Google Search towards AI features during the recent earnings call.
- The transformation aims to make Search function more like an AI assistant by 2025, expanding the universe of queries users can ask.
- Project Astra and Gemini Deep Research are key initiatives that will enhance AI capabilities in Search.
- The introduction of features allowing users to interact more like with a chatbot is being considered.
- Despite prior issues with AI overviews providing inaccurate information, Google remains determined to integrate more AI into Search.

items.title: Krafton leads Cashfree’s $53M funding at $700M valuation
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Cashfree raised $53 million in Series C funding, led by Krafton, valuing the startup at $700 million.
- The Bengaluru-based payments startup processes over $80 billion annually for more than 800,000 businesses, including Swiggy and Bajaj Finance.
- Cashfree is expanding into international markets, particularly focusing on the UAE.
- Founded in 2015, Cashfree has seen a 130% surge in merchant sign-ups this fiscal year.
- Cashfree processes up to 12,000 transactions per second and has completed over a billion identity verifications with SecureID.

items.title: Brightpick’s new warehouse robot can reach 20-foot-high shelves
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Brightpick announced the Giraffe system, capable of reaching up to 20 feet to pick items from warehouse shelves.
- The Giraffe features a telescoping arm and works in conjunction with the existing Autopicker robot.
- Giraffe will be deployed in 2025 for major customers, including The Feed and McGuff Company, improving warehouse density by 3x compared to manual operations.

items.title: Alphabet praises DeepSeek, but it’s massively ramping up its AI spending
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- DeepSeek affected Nvidia's stock, raising concerns over AI demand for chips.
- Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai lauded DeepSeek's achievements during earnings call.
- Alphabet plans to increase capital expenditures by 42% to $75 billion this year to enhance AI operations.
- Pichai believes cheaper AI will drive higher demand for Alphabet's services, leveraging its existing user base.
- Similar commitments to AI investment were made by Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg recently.

items.title: Snap says TikTok uncertainty benefited its business
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- During Snap’s Q4 earnings call, CEO Evan Spiegel stated that TikTok's uncertainty has positively benefited their business.
- He noted that the engagement lift during TikTok's brief offline period was encouraging for Snap.
- Snapchat's Spotlight feature is attracting more creators, with over 40% growth in content posting year-over-year in Q4.
- Snap has reached 453 million daily active users, an increase of 39 million from the previous period, and reported a revenue of $1.55 billion in Q4.
- The uncertainty around TikTok has also positively impacted the broader social media landscape, boosting user engagement in several apps.

items.title: A16z hires acquitted former Marine Daniel Penny as an investor
items.summary:
- Andreessen Horowitz (A16z) hires Daniel Penny as an investor.
- Penny was acquitted of criminally negligent homicide in a high-profile case involving a homeless man on a NYC subway.
- Despite lacking investment experience, A16z will provide training for Penny in its American Dynamism practice.
- The case surrounding Penny's actions in 2023 polarized public opinion.

items.title: AMD Pulls Up the Release of Its Next-Gen Data Center GPUs
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- AMD plans to launch the AMD Instinct MI350 series data center GPUs sooner than expected, with sampling for lead customers this quarter.
- CEO Lisa Su announced an acceleration in production shipments to mid-2025, up from the second half of 2025 due to strong customer demand.
- AMD's data center revenue reached $5 billion in 2024, contributing significantly to the company's overall revenue, with expectations for double-digit growth in 2025.

items.title: Miist, founded by a 25-year-old, wants people to vape their way out of smoking addiction and migraines
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Dalton Signor founded Miist Therapeutics while in university, aiming to combat smoking addiction and migraines.
- Miist's inhaler delivers medication rapidly to the lungs, achieving a 92% craving reduction in smokers within two minutes during Phase I trials.
- The startup has secured $7 million in seed funding from various investors, focusing on innovative delivery methods for nicotine and migraine relief.

items.title: Google removes pledge to not use AI for weapons from website
items.summary:
- Google removed its pledge to not develop AI for weapons or surveillance from its public AI principles page on February 4, 2025.
- The change was first reported by Bloomberg, indicating an erasure of the section on applications the company would not pursue.
- The updated AI principles highlight Google's commitment to mitigating harmful outcomes and supporting national security, despite previous employee protests over military contracts.

items.title: Spyware maker Paragon confirms U.S. government is a customer
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
[Paragon Solutions confirmed it sells spyware to the U.S. government and allied countries.]
[The company has a zero-tolerance policy against targeting journalists and civil society figures.]
[WhatsApp alleged that Paragon's spyware was used in a hacking campaign against journalists, with at least two targets coming forward.]

items.title: Okta competitor SailPoint races toward $11.5B IPO
items.summary:
- Cybersecurity company SailPoint plans to go public with a valuation of $11.5 billion.
- The proposed IPO includes selling 47.5 million shares priced between $19 to $21, raising $1 billion.
- SailPoint was previously public until being taken private by Thoma Bravo in 2022 at a $6.9 billion valuation.
- The company expects $813 million in annual recurring revenue and reported $395 million in net losses with $700 million in revenues as of January 2024.
- SailPoint has more than $1 billion in debt and plans to use IPO proceeds to address this debt and fund operations.
- The IPO's timing is significant for venture capitalists and tech startups looking for market signals for their own offerings.

items.title: Figure drops OpenAI in favor of in-house models
items.author: Brett Adcock
items.summary:
- Figure AI CEO Brett Adcock announced the company is exiting its partnership with OpenAI to focus on in-house AI development.
- The decision follows a major breakthrough that promises to reveal something unprecedented in humanoid technology within 30 days.
- Figure has raised a total of $1.5 billion, with the last funding round valuing the company at $2.6 billion.
- OpenAI had previously collaborated with Figure on AI models for humanoid robots; Adcock cites integration challenges as a reason for the split.
- Figure will prioritize vertical integration for powering humanoid robots, contrasting with OpenAI's broader focus.
- OpenAI filed a trademark application hinting at developing humanoid robots, underscoring a potential shift in its own strategy.

items.title: Hugging Face researchers aim to build an ‘open’ version of OpenAI’s deep research tool
items.author: Thomas Wolf
items.summary:
- Researchers at Hugging Face have developed an open version called Open Deep Research, based on OpenAI’s deep research tool.
- OpenAI's original tool is part of a $200/month ChatGPT Pro plan and compiles research reports by crawling the web.
- Open Deep Research incorporates OpenAI's o1 model and an open-source framework, allowing for autonomous web navigation and analysis.
- Initial tests showed Open Deep Research achieving a GAIA benchmark score of 54%, compared to 67.36% for OpenAI’s tool.
- A public demo was launched but faced high traffic issues, with users experiencing errors during testing.
- The source code for Open Deep Research is available on GitHub for further development and user feedback.

items.title: Amazon continues renewable energy spree with 476 MW purchase
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Amazon signed contracts to purchase 476 megawatts of wind and solar energy on the Iberian Peninsula.
- The agreements with Iberdrola are to support new data centers planned in the region as part of a $17 billion investment in infrastructure, announced last May.
- The Tâmega wind farm will collaborate with a hydroelectric dam system in Portugal, utilizing pumped-storage to balance energy supply.

items.title: A review of Tapestry, an app powered by the growing open web
items.summary:
- A new app called [Tapestry](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/tapestry-by-iconfactory/id6448078074) launched on February 4, 2025, to aggregate and organize information from across the web.
- It aims to reduce the need for app-switching by providing a single platform for updates from various social networks and RSS feeds.
- The app is built by the creators of the original Twitter client, Twitterrific, and introduces a customizable timeline feature.
- Users can filter content and create custom timelines for specific interests such as news or social networks.
- While it offers a unique solution, the app's user interface can feel complicated, and requires users to engage in feed creation.
- Tapestry faces competition from other apps like [Bluesky](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/03/what-is-bluesky-everything-to-know-about-the-x-competitor/) and [Flipboard's Surf](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/18/flipboard-launches-surf-a-new-app-for-browsing-the-open-social-web/).

items.title: E-fuels startup will make diamonds before powering jet planes
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Stephen Beaton, after a military career, founded Circularity Fuels to create liquid fuels.
- Circularity Fuels plans to start with lab-grown diamonds before moving to aviation fuels.
- The company produces methane from CO₂ and hydrogen using a unique reactor and catalyst, which drastically reduces energy consumption.
- Circularity has received $4.9 million in grants and recently became an ARPA-E awardee, aiming to disrupt fossil fuel markets with e-fuels.

items.title: TED Talks has put out an all-call for a new leader
items.author: Chris Anderson
items.summary:
- Chris Anderson, who has run TED for 25 years, announces an open call for a new leader.
- TED is known for its diverse TED Talks featuring figures like Bill Gates and Elon Musk.
- The organization includes live events, a media empire, and a charity with a $25 million reserve.
- The applicant process is open to anyone, and TED operates as a nonprofit.

items.title: Challenging Bluesky, Threads now allows for public custom feeds
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Meta’s Threads is enhancing custom feeds to compete with Bluesky, which has over 30 million users.
- Users can now set their custom feeds to public and follow feeds created by others.
- Threads aims for user-friendly custom feed creation without requiring technical skills.
- Custom feeds allow users to personalize their experience and pin liked feeds to their home screen.
- The feature launch is a strategic move to counter Bluesky's growth and retain user engagement.
- Users can make feeds public, share them via links or DMs, and find them under a new 'Feeds' tab on profiles.
- Custom feeds can be based on various topics like sports, art, and fashion, unlike Bluesky's broader sorting options.

items.title: This Week in AI: Billionaires talk automating jobs away
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman discussed AI automation with SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son in Tokyo.
- SoftBank plans to spend $3 billion annually on OpenAI products, aiming to automate millions of white-collar workflows.
- Concerns rise about widespread job automation leading to significant unemployment amidst industry excitement over AI capabilities.

items.title: An angel investor was so intrigued by this startup, he joined as a co-founder
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Lily Vittayarukskul started the AI-driven startup **Waterlily** in late 2021 to help families navigate long-term care costs.
- Evan Ehrenberg, a former angel investor, joined the company as a co-founder in 2022 after being impressed by the platform's predictions.
- Ehrenberg has a background in founding and selling the company **Clara Health**, and is also MIT’s youngest neuroscience PhD.

items.title: Okta lays off 180 employees – nearly one year after last workforce reduction
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Okta laid off 180 employees on Tuesday, just over a year after laying off 400 workers.
- The recent layoff affected approximately 3% of its workforce, which was around 5300 prior to the cuts.
- This follows earlier reductions in February 2023, which impacted 300 employees.
- Despite layoffs, Okta reported a fiscal third-quarter revenue of $665 million, a 14% increase from the previous year.

items.title: China may probe Intel for antitrust: report
items.summary:
- Intel potentially facing an antitrust probe from China amid U.S. tariff tensions.
- China announced tariffs against the U.S. and reopened an antitrust investigation into Google.
- Intel's significant revenue in China accounted for 29% of its global earnings, approximately $15.5 billion in the last year.

items.title: EU puts out guidance on uses of AI that are banned under its AI Act
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- The EU AI Act compliance deadline was recently initiated, banning “unacceptable risk” AI use-cases such as social scoring.
- The EU Commission released guidance to help developers comply, highlighting severe penalties for violations.
- The guidelines are illustrative and not legally binding; enforcement will be managed by regulators and courts.
- Formal adoption of the guidelines is pending translation into various EU languages.
- Further compliance deadlines will occur in the future; EU Member States have until August 2 to appoint oversight bodies for the AI Act.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2024 and 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary:
- In 2024, more than 150,000 job cuts occurred across 542 tech companies.
- Major layoffs reported by companies such as [Tesla](https://techcrunch.com/2024/04/15/tesla-layoffs-workers-sales-cybertruck-cuts/), [Amazon](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/amazon-prime-video-and-mgm-studios-laid-off-hundreds-of-employees/), [Google](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/google-cuts-hundreds-of-jobs-in-its-voice-assistance-hardware-teams-as-fitbit-founders-leave/), [TikTok](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/23/tiktok-lays-off-60-employees/), [Snap](https://techcrunch.com/2024/02/05/snapchats-parent-lays-off-10-of-workforce-in-order-to-reduce-hierarchy-says-company/), and [Microsoft](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/25/microsoft-lays-off-1900-employees-in-activision-blizzard-and-xbox-divisions/).
- Layoffs are also expected to continue into 2025, with tracking efforts ongoing.
- The layoffs reflect trends in the tech industry, as companies adapt to economic challenges and the increasing adoption of AI and automation.

items.title: Cruise to slash workforce by nearly 50% after GM cuts funding to robotaxi operations
items.summary:
- Cruise is laying off nearly 50% of its workforce, including top executives, due to a strategy shift after GM cut funding for its robotaxi operations.
- The layoffs were confirmed in a company-wide email from Cruise's president, affecting more than 1,000 employees out of approximately 2,100.
- Laid-off employees will receive severance packages, with benefits extending through April, and support for job searching.
- GM completed its acquisition of Cruise, now a wholly-owned subsidiary, and aims to save up to $1 billion annually by ending its robotaxi development.
- The layoffs follow GM's prior decision to pivot from commercial robotaxi development to focusing on personal autonomous vehicles, announced in December 2024.

items.title: Deel unloads $300M in secondary sale, brings General Catalyst on as an investor
items.summary:
- Deel's annual revenue run rate grew by 70% to $800 million in 2024.
- The company sold $300 million in secondary shares to General Catalyst and an unnamed sovereign investor.
- Reports suggest the unnamed investor is Mubadala Investment Company, Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund.
- Deel is preparing for an IPO potentially as soon as next year, with previous indications for 2025/2026.
- Following the secondary sale, Deel's valuation increased to $12.6 billion.
- Deel has filed a motion to dismiss a lawsuit alleging it enabled money laundering.

items.title: DSTLRY Launches New Customization Features for Artists in Digital Comics Marketplace
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- DSTLRY has introduced two new features: Commissioned Digital Remarques and Unlimited Digital Covers.
- Commissioned Digital Remarques allow creators to add personalized sketches and signatures to digital comics, replicating traditional comic customization.
- Unlimited Digital Covers maintains the availability of both main and alternative covers in digital circulation for the book's lifecycle, enhancing collectability while still offering some scarcity.

items.title: How Max Altschuler accidentally founded a VC firm that just raised another $54M
items.summary:
- GTMfund founder Max Altschuler raised a second fund of $54 million after originally aiming for $50 million.
- The fund is backed by operators from successful tech companies like AWS and OpenAI, focusing on mentoring portfolio companies in sales strategies.
- Fund II attracted 300 operator LPs and six institutional investors, building on the success of the first fund launched in 2021, which included 250 operators and backed notable companies such as AI composer Writer and data center tech Atlan.
- GTMfund aims to invest in about 40 early-stage companies, with check sizes ranging from $500,000 to $1.5 million.

items.title: Apple launches Invites, a new app for creating custom invitations
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Apple launched a new app called “Invites” for creating custom invitations for occasions.
- Users require an iCloud+ subscription to create invitations, but anyone can RSVP.
- Invites competes with third-party apps like Partiful and services such as evite and Paperless Post.
- The app features event integration with Maps and Weather, allowing guests to get directions and weather updates.
- Users can create event soundtracks with Apple Music and collaborate on a Shared Album for photos and videos.
- Hosts can manage events, share invite links, and adjust visible invitation details.
- Apple Invites is free for iPhone models running iOS 18 or later and accessible on the web via icloud.com/invites.

items.title: Former Tesla engineer heading government agency reportedly outlines ‘AI-first strategy’
items.author: Thomas Shedd
items.summary:
- Thomas Shedd, a former Tesla engineer, is now the director of Technology Transformation Services.
- Shedd outlined an "AI-first strategy" for the U.S. government to run the office like a "startup software company."
- The initiative is part of a cost-cutting measure, with the department facing a potential 50% budget cut.
- Shedd aims to create a centralized government contract database designed for AI analysis.

items.title: Deepfake videos are getting shockingly good
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Researchers from ByteDance demonstrated a new AI system, [OmniHuman-1](https://omnihuman-lab.github.io/), which generates highly realistic deepfake videos.
- Unlike previous deepfakes, OmniHuman-1 can produce convincing videos using just one reference image and audio.
- The system shows significant improvements but still struggles with low-quality images and certain poses.
- Deepfakes have been part of spreading misinformation and financial fraud, causing substantial losses in recent years.
- An open letter from the AI community calls for strict regulations on deepfakes; some states are enacting laws against AI impersonation.
- Public concern is rising as a survey indicates 60% of people encountered deepfakes in the past year, with many fearing they could be misled.

items.title: LogicStar is building AI agents for app maintenance
items.summary:
- Swiss startup [LogicStar](https://logicstar.ai/) focuses on developing AI agents for autonomous app maintenance, securing $3 million in pre-seed funding.
- CEO Boris Paskalev emphasizes the goal to resolve software bugs more effectively than current AI models by utilizing a test-driven development approach.
- The startup's technology currently supports Python, with plans to expand to Typescript, Javascript, and Java, targeting enterprises for implementation.

items.title: Two space startups have merged to create the next generation of telescopes
items.summary:
- OurSky and PlaneWave Instruments are merging to form a new company called Observable Space.
- The merger aims to create more user-friendly telescopes and integrate various components for ease of use.
- Observable Space has already raised $11 million and counts NASA and the U.S. Space Force among its customers.
